turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: You know what they say -- there's nothing like home.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: That's right... and we might as well face it.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Let's be happy that we're all alive.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: And that's something we owe to Ninotchka.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: What a lovely room you have here.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: How many families live here with you?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: She's right...  anyhow let's talk ourselves into it.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Just see how happy the people look... from here....

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: And if it is too late for you your children will eat it.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Let's forget the future... let's stop being sentimental... let's start that omelet.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: We can say whatever we want. We can shout... we can complain... Look...  The service in this hotel is terrible!  See? Nobody comes... nobody pays any attention. That's freedom.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: No, that's bad management.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Is there anything I can do for you, monsieur?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: I am Comrade Buljanoff.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Monsieur.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: May I ask how much your rooms are?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Well, gentlemen, I'm afraid our rates are rather high.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Why should you be afraid?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: How are things in Moscow?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Very good. The last mass trials were a great success. There are going to be fewer but better Russians.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: This is the apartment we have reserved for you, Comrade Yakushova. I hope you like it.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Which part of the room is mine?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Which lawyer?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You didn't get legal advice?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: We didn't want to get mixed up with lawyers. They are very expensive here. If you just say hello to a lawyer... well, there goes another cow.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrade Buljanoff...

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Yes, Comrade?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Do you spell Buljanoff with one or two f's?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: With two f's, if you please.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Is there anything I can do, Comrade?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You might get me an accurate map of Paris. I want to use my spare time to inspect the public utilities and make a study of all outstanding technical achievements in the city.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Yes, Comrade.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: There's something else which I know will appeal to you. A visit to the Paris sewers. They tell me it is extremely instructive.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Huh?... Why don't you get a haircut, Buljanoff? You all look so wintry, Comrades. And why do we always keep the windows closed?  Isn't it amazing, at home there's still snow and ice and here... Look at the birds. I always felt a little hurt that our swallows deserted us in the winter for capitalistic countries. Now I know why. We have the high ideal but they have the climate... well, Comrades, I don't think I need you any more.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Now let's forget everything except that we're together.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Let's not close our eyes. There are many good things to see here too.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: I think I need my glasses.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Comrades... I'm out of the omelet.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't worry... there will be enough.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: It is high time you got out of Russia.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I must be stern with you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't forget, the day will come when you will have to face Razinin.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Good old Razinin! Is he still alive? How does he manage?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: But, Comrades...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Is it possible to bring you back to reality for a moment? I must have a complete report of your negotiations and a detailed expense account.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Don't ask for it, Ninotchka. There is a Turkish proverb which says, "If something smells bad, why put your nose in it?"

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And there is a Russian saying: "The cat who has cream on his whiskers had better find good excuses."

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: With our cream situation what it is, it is Russia which should apologize to the cats.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Friends... friends, Buljanoff, Iranoff...

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: All you have to do is say "open sesame."

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I don't know how I can get you out of it this time. How will it end? What will happen to you?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Shall we tell her?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Guest?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: We have opened a restaurant...

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: We are not only serving good food, we are serving our country... we are making friends.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Who gave you this idea? What is responsible for all this?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: You think because you represent the former Duchess...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: The Duchess...

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: The former Duchess!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: In any case, gentlemen, a charming, beautiful, exquisite woman. I warn you, if this case comes to trial it will be before a French court, and when the Duchess takes the stand...

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Not that we are giving in one inch, but tell us... what is in your mind?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, gentlemen, how about my proposition?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: About this telegram to Moscow. Why should you bother? I'll write it for you.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Leon... Leonitchka...  Why are you so good to us?

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Didn't we put up a strong resistance?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, yes, yes.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Boys, boys... don't forget Russia is your mother country. Three sons walking out all at once... that's too much for any mother.

turns.speaker: BULJANOFF
turns.text: Well, if your mother turns against you, you have to look for someone to adopt you.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Good morning, Your Highness.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Good morning, Gaston.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Count d'Algout is still asleep.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That's all right.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Nonsense. How can you fight the Reds and make yourself agreeable to the Whites if you don't keep up your strength.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Shall I draw your bath, sir?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: A blue shirt, perhaps?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Blue? Let's offset his mood. Find a striped one, and brighten it with a great blaze of tie.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Very well, Your Highness.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Good evening, Gaston.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Good evening, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Count d'Algout, there have been several telephone...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Go to bed.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Your breakfast, monsieur.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I don't feel like any breakfast.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What time have you, Gaston?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Eight forty-two, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I guess it is eight forty-two.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I am, Gaston.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Have you?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?

turns.speaker: GASTON
turns.text: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SAVITZKY
turns.text: Your Highness...

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Yes, General Savitzky?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SAVITZKY
turns.text: I want you to know all the White Russian exiles in Paris are keeping their fingers crossed about the jewels. They are very interested in the case. Swana suspects her countrymen.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Are they indeed? Thank you.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SAVITZKY
turns.text: They hope the settlement will bring you a fortune.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: General, please... if you hear any rumors that I am a charitable person, will you please kill them at their source?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: You're looking magnificent, Leon...  ...isn't he, General Savitzky?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SAVITZKY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: General, would you mind making my excuses at our table? I'll be back in a few moments.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SAVITZKY
turns.text: Certainly.

turns.speaker: HEADWAITER
turns.text: Good evening, Your Highness.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Good evening, Louis. You seem to be very crowded tonight. Can you manage a table near the floor?

turns.speaker: HEADWAITER
turns.text: Certainly, Your Highness, this way please... Count d'Algout made the reservation this afternoon.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Count d'Algout...

turns.speaker: HEADWAITER
turns.text: It is only a small table but it will be no trouble to put in some extra chairs.

turns.speaker: HEADWAITER
turns.text: Only one in the rear, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: That's perfect!

turns.speaker: HEADWAITER
turns.text: Is this satisfactory?

turns.speaker: SWANA
turns.text: Thank you, Louis.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Comrades, why should we lie to each other? It's wonderful.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Let's be honest. Have we anything like it in Russia?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: They tell me when you ring once the valet comes in; when you ring twice you get the waiter; and do you know what happens when you ring three times? A maid comes in -- a French maid.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Comrades, if we ring nine times... let's go in.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: I don't want to go to the Hotel Terminus.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: If Lenin were alive he would say, "Buljanoff, Comrade, for once in your life you're in Paris. Don't be a fool. Go in there and ring three times."

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: He wouldn't say that. What he would say is "Buljanoff, you can't afford to live in a cheap hotel. Doesn't the prestige of the Bolsheviks mean anything to you? Do you want to live in a hotel where you press for the hot water and cold water comes and when you press for the cold water nothing comes out at all? Phooey, Buljanoff!"

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We can wait.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Do we give the impression of people who are pressed for money?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: You know, Monsieur Mercier, this is all non-sense.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: These may have been the jewels of the Duchess Swana, but, like all private property, they were confiscated by the State.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We can call our ambassador.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: I give you my word! They were confiscated legally!

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: That won't help you! You can't intimidate us!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Soviet Russia will put all its might behind this case.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Yes, Leon...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: What is it, my boy?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Leon, my little boy.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Oh, Leon, you are so good.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Halt negotiations immediately. Envoy extraordinary arrives Thursday six ten with full power. Your authority cancelled herewith. Razinin.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: It is Thursday!

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: This is a fine thing. Maybe we've missed him already.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: How can you find somebody without knowing what he looks like?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We don't blame you, Leon, but when we came from Russia we believed in simplicity...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: We avoided luxury and extravagance and today... well, if you were to offer us a glass of champagne, we wouldn't say no.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: They tell me it has a wonderful restaurant on the second floor.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: While you eat, you look at the view.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Let's do that.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: It's a real Paris reunion.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: If you close your eyes and listen to our voices we might be in Paris.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: ...des petites fraises des bois... de la crème de Bretagne...

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: ...so it blows up that big... what they call an Omelette Surprise!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Well, I think it's getting late. Good night, Ninotchka.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Thank you for a wonderful dinner.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: That was our idea when we first came. All we thought we would get out of this trip was a Turkish bath, but... we learned better.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Ninotchka, we are in the magic East, the country of Aladdin and His Lamp...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: ...Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves... into one single hour you can crowd a thousand and one nights.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Don't call it desertion. Our little restaurant... that is our Russia... the Russia of borscht, the Russia of beef Stroganoff, blinis with sour cream...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: ...the Russia of piroshki... people will eat and love it.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: There's something in Constantinople... something irresistible....

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: ...it is in the air... it may come around the corner as you walk down the street....

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: We don't want to be disturbed.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: My name is Count d'Algout. I telephoned.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: If you want to see us you must come later.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I just want a word with Monsieur Mercier.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: But you can't...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, gentlemen... how about a little lunch?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Get out of here!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Don't look so gloomy, gentlemen. All is not lost. You may have a chance.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: All right, go ahead, get her on the witness stand! What can she say?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: But how will she look? The fashions this spring are very becoming to her. Gentlemen, the judge will be French, the jury will be French, everybody in that courtroom will be French. Have you ever seen a French court when a beautiful woman sits on the witness stand and lifts her skirt a little? You sit down and pull up your pants and where will it get you?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: I suppose you expect us to hand over the jewels?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Oh, no, no. I am not a highwayman, I'm just a nuisance. All I'm trying to do is make things as difficult as possible.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: What proposition?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I just said let's have a little lunch.  Room service.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What's the name of that Commissar on the Board of Trade?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Razinin.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Razinin, Board of Trade, Moscow.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: And if we have to go to Siberia...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: I'll send you a muff.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: She says she won't be intimidated by parasites. She called the Duchess a blood-sucking aristocrat and a blackmailer.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What did she say about me?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: I think she covered you with the parasites.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: You found your way to us and we weren't easy to reach, were we?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am looking for Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: I am Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am Nina Ivanovna Yakushova, Envoy Extraordinary, acting under direct orders of Comrade Commissar Razinin. Present me to your colleagues.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Comrade Buljanoff...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrade.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Comrade Kopalski...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Comrade.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: What a charming idea for Moscow to surprise us with a lady comrade.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How much does this cost?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Two thousand francs.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: A week?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: A day.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Do you know how much a cow costs, Comrade Iranoff?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: A cow?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Two thousand francs. If I stay here a week I will cost the Russian people seven cows.  Who am I to cost the Russian people seven cows?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Well, it means another two weeks in Paris.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Too bad we have to waste all that time.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Come, now, you must not talk that way.... You have to adjust yourselves.... We must be brave.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Brave... that's right.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Only myself and two other girls. One is a cello player in the opera and the other a street-car conductor.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Just three people in a room this size? Whew!

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Bad news?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Look for yourselves.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: But Buljanoff, Iranoff, Kopalski...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Now, please, Ninotchka, don't start figuring it out in cows.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You've done it again and I am responsible. How can you forget yourselves this way? You were sent here to make money, not to spend it.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Buljanoff, she still has those old- fashioned Bolshevik ideas.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: ...we have a wonderful electric sign: "Dine With Buljanof, Iranoff, and Kopalski."

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You mean you are deserting Russia?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Yes, monsieur?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Just looking around.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: This is Comrade Kopalski.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Monsieur.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: I might be able to accommodate you. Is there some more luggage?

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Oh, yes, but have you a safe here big enough to hold this?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: I'm afraid we have no boxes of that size in our vault, but there is one suite with a private safe...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: That's even better.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: But, gentlemen, I am afraid...

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: A Special Envoy is coming from Moscow. He'll occupy the Royal Suite. Move our things to the smallest room you've got.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Yes, monsieur.

turns.speaker: IRANOFF
turns.text: Right away... instantly!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Now, monsieur, you have no right...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Just a moment.  I hope you haven't closed this deal, Monsieur Mercier. It might bring you into serious difficulties.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We may have a chance.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Yes... a very slim one. I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We haven't anything to discuss with you. We'll talk to a lawyer!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: All right -- go ahead... you talk to the lawyer and I'll talk to the judge!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: How does this strike you? Commissar Razinin, Board of Trade, Moscow. Unexpected situation here. Duchess Swana in Paris claims jewels, and has already brought injunction against sale or removal. After long and careful study we suggest in the interest of our beloved country a fifty-fifty settlement as best solution. Iranoff, Buljanoff, and Kopalski.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: If we say that, Leon... we'll be sent to Siberia!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: What's new?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Leon, Leonitchka, she is not going to negotiate! She is going to fight that injunction. She's going to make a precedent of it!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Well, boys, I'd like to help you but what can I do? Yesterday I waited six hours in the lobby!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: She doesn't leave her room! She has been locked in for the last two days with lawyers and law books!

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: All right, then make an appointment with her so I can see her!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We can't... but you are so ingenious, Leon...

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: If we had known we would have greeted you with flowers.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't make an issue of my womanhood. We are here for work... all of us. Let's not waste time. Shall we go?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: He is a porter. He wants to carry them.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Why?... Why should you carry other people's bags?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Allow me, Comrade.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: It's a hat, Comrade, a woman's hat.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I am ashamed to put the picture of Lenin in a room like this.  Comrades, your telegram was received with great disfavor in Moscow.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We did our best, Comrade.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I hope so for your sake.  Let us examine the case. What does the lawyer say?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We dealt directly with the representative of the Grand Duchess. I am sure if we call him he will give you a very clear picture.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: I will not repeat your mistake. I will have no dealings with the Grand Duchess nor her representative.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Will you send me some cigarettes, please?  Comrades, I am not in a position to pass final judgment but at best you have been careless in your duty to the State.  You were entrusted with more than a mere sale of jewelry. Why are we peddling our precious possessions to the world at this time? Our next year's crop is in danger and you know it. Unless we can get foreign currency to buy tractors there will not be enough bread for our people. And you three comrades...

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: We did it with the best intentions...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: We cannot feed the Russian people on your intentions. Fifty per cent to a so-called Duchess!... Half of every loaf of bread to our enemy! Comrade Kopalski, go at once to our Embassy and get the address of the best lawyer in Paris.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Yes, Comrade.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: You, Comrade Iranoff, go to the Public Library and get me the section of the Civil Code on property.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: I acted on your suggestion and got in touch with the Power and Light authorities. Whenever you want to visit their plants they are open to you.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Oh yes, Power and Light. Thank you.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: If there is anything we can do for you...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: No, not a thing. Would you like to go out?

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: How are you, you three scoundrels?

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Well, we're back home.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: And your own gas cooker? That's marvelous!  Naturally it's not the Royal Suite...

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Sssh! Once and for all, we're in Moscow!

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Yes, there's no doubt of that...  Just look out of the window and there it is.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: And it's great! Think what it was a few years ago and what it is now.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: The same spring we had in Paris. Just as good.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Even the swallows are back.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Now, comrades... there is something better in life than crumbs of French pastry.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: Yes, a good piece of apfel strudel....

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: We will get that... we'll get everything... maybe a little bit later but we'll get it... We must be patient... Finally we got the spring, didn't we? We got the swallows, and you will get your apfel strudel too.

turns.speaker: KOPALSKI
turns.text: ...and Kopalski.

turns.speaker: NINOTCHKA
turns.text: Don't make it difficult for me. This is no more a pleasure trip for me than it is for you.
